sn12.43:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and disappearance of suffering.

sn12.43:1.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn12.43:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.43:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.43:2.1.eng: “And what, mendicants, is the origin of suffering?

sn12.43:2.2.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.43:2.2.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
sn12.43:2.2.comm: This discourse (and the next two) begin with consciousness in the process of sense stimulation. They offer a compressed sequence that focuses on the arising of suffering in the present life, and how by letting go craving it is possible to not generate a future life.

sn12.43:2.3.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.43:2.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving. …
sn12.43:2.4.comm: The text jumps straight from craving to suffering, although the full sequence is stated in the cessation series. The next discourse, which is otherwise similar, lists all the factors, and the one after that goes to grasping, then indicates an abbreviation. I think the full sequence is meant in every case, and the sign of abbreviation in the Pali text is missing by mistake.

sn12.43:2.5.eng: This is the origin of suffering.

sn12.43:3.1.pli: Sotañca paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ …pe…
sn12.43:3.1.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

sn12.43:3.2.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. …

sn12.43:3.3.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. …

sn12.43:3.4.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. …

sn12.43:3.5.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.43:3.5.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.43:3.6.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.43:3.7.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving. …

sn12.43:3.8.eng: This is the origin of suffering.

sn12.43:4.1.eng: And what is the disappearance of suffering?

sn12.43:4.2.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.43:4.2.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.43:4.3.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.43:4.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.43:4.5.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.
sn12.43:4.5.comm: Craving can cease without leading to grasping for one practicing the path.

sn12.43:4.6.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn12.43:4.7.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn12.43:4.8.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn12.43:4.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.43:4.10.eng: This is the disappearance of suffering.

sn12.43:5.1.pli: Sotañca paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ …pe…
sn12.43:5.1.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

sn12.43:5.2.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. …

sn12.43:5.3.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. …

sn12.43:5.4.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. …

sn12.43:5.5.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.43:5.5.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.43:5.6.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.43:5.7.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.43:5.8.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn12.43:5.9.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn12.43:5.10.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn12.43:5.11.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn12.43:5.12.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.43:5.13.eng: This is the disappearance of suffering.”

sn12.44:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and disappearance of the world.

sn12.44:1.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn12.44:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.44:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.44:2.1.eng: “And what, mendicants, is the origin of the world?

sn12.44:2.2.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.44:2.2.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.44:2.3.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.44:2.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.44:2.5.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn12.44:2.6.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn12.44:2.7.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn12.44:2.8.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn12.44:2.9.eng: This is the origin of the world.

sn12.44:3.1.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

sn12.44:3.2.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. …

sn12.44:3.3.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. …

sn12.44:3.4.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. …

sn12.44:3.5.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.44:3.5.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.44:3.6.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling. …

sn12.44:3.7.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn12.44:3.8.eng: This is the origin of the world.

sn12.44:4.1.eng: And what is the ending of the world?

sn12.44:4.2.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.44:4.2.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.44:4.3.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.44:4.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.44:4.5.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn12.44:4.6.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn12.44:4.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.44:4.8.eng: This is the ending of the world.

sn12.44:5.1.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

sn12.44:5.2.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. …

sn12.44:5.3.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. …

sn12.44:5.4.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. …

sn12.44:5.5.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.44:5.5.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.44:5.6.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.44:5.7.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.44:5.8.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn12.44:5.9.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn12.44:5.10.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.44:5.11.eng: This is the ending of the world.”

sn12.45:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā ñātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
sn12.45:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.
sn12.45:1.2.comm: Ñātika (also spelled nātika, or nādika; Sanskrit jñātṛka; Prākrit nāyika) was the clan to which the Jain leader Mahāvīra (called Nāṭaputta, i.e. Ñātiputta) belonged. Here it is the name of their chief town.

sn12.45:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rahogato paṭisallāno imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ abhāsi:
sn12.45:1.3.eng: Then while the Buddha was in private retreat he spoke this exposition of the teaching:

sn12.45:2.1.pli: “Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.45:2.1.eng: “Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.45:2.2.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.45:2.3.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.45:2.4.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping. …

sn12.45:2.5.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.45:3.1.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

sn12.45:3.2.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. …

sn12.45:3.3.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. …

sn12.45:3.4.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. …

sn12.45:3.5.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.45:3.5.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.45:3.6.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.45:3.7.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.45:3.8.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping. …

sn12.45:3.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.45:4.1.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.45:4.1.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.45:4.2.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.45:4.3.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.45:4.4.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn12.45:4.5.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn12.45:4.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.45:5.1.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

sn12.45:5.2.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn12.45:5.2.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn12.45:5.3.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn12.45:5.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn12.45:5.5.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn12.45:5.6.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn12.45:5.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.45:6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu bhagavato upassuti ṭhito hoti.
sn12.45:6.1.eng: Now at that time a certain monk was standing listening in on the Buddha.

sn12.45:6.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ upassuti ṭhitaṃ.

sn12.45:6.4.eng: “Monk, did you hear that exposition of the teaching?”

sn12.45:6.9.eng: That exposition of the teaching is beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

sn12.46:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn12.46:1.2.eng: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn12.46:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.46:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

sn12.46:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama, so karoti so paṭisaṃvedayatī”ti?
sn12.46:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, are he who does the deed and he who experiences the result one and the same?”

sn12.46:2.2.pli: “‘So karoti so paṭisaṃvedayatī’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, ayameko anto”.
sn12.46:2.2.eng: “‘He who does the deed and he who experiences the result are one and the same’: this is one extreme, brahmin.”

sn12.46:3.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bho gotama, añño karoti, añño paṭisaṃvedayatī”ti?
sn12.46:3.1.eng: “Then is he who does the deed one and he who experiences the result another?”

sn12.46:3.2.pli: “‘Añño karoti, añño paṭisaṃvedayatī’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, ayaṃ dutiyo anto.
sn12.46:3.2.eng: “‘He who does the deed is one and he who experiences the result is another’: this is the second extreme.

sn12.46:3.3.pli: Ete te, brāhmaṇa, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.46:3.3.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.46:3.5.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.46:3.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.46:3.7.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.46:3.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’”

sn12.46:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.46:4.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin said to the Buddha,

sn12.46:4.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn12.46:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn12.47:1.2.pli: Atha kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.47:1.2.eng: Then the brahmin Jānussoṇi went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. Seated to one side he said to the Buddha:
sn12.47:1.2.comm: We meet Jānussoṇi many times in the Suttas as a prominent brahmin who converses with the Buddha on a number of topics, with a special interest in the afterlife. His name appears in Sanskrit as Jānaśruti or Jānaśruteya, which are patronymics of Janaśruti, “famed among the people”. The Pali commentary says it is a title awarded the family priest (purohita) of Kosala, which would make him one of the most powerful brahmins alive. However, I can find no confirmation of such a title, whereas the use of Jānaśruti as a patronymic by the descendants of Janaśruti is well attested. One such, perhaps the same individual we meet in the Suttas, features in Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.1–3 as a generous seeker of the truth.

sn12.47:2.2.eng: “‘All exists’: this is one extreme, brahmin.”

sn12.47:3.2.pli: “‘Sabbaṃ natthī’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, ayaṃ dutiyo anto.
sn12.47:3.2.eng: “‘All does not exist’: this is the second extreme.

sn12.47:3.3.pli: Ete te, brāhmaṇa, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.47:3.3.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.47:3.5.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.47:3.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.47:3.7.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.47:3.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’”

sn12.47:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.47:4.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin Jānussoṇi said to the Buddha,

sn12.47:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn12.48:1.2.pli: Atha kho lokāyatiko brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā …pe…
sn12.48:1.2.eng: Then a brahmin cosmologist went up to the Buddha …
sn12.48:1.2.comm: “Cosmology” (lokāyata) was a branch of Vedic study concerned with the nature and extent of the world and how this may be known (AN 9.38, SN 12.48; cf. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.3.1). Vedic metaphysics posited “existence” as a primordial “oneness” from which the diversity of the world spread out.

sn12.48:1.3.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho lokāyatiko brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.48:1.3.eng: Seated to one side he said to the Buddha:

sn12.48:2.2.eng: “‘All exists’: this is the oldest cosmology, brahmin.”
sn12.48:2.2.comm: The “oldest cosmology” is quite literal. The oldest Indian cosmology is found in a few late Rig Vedic hymns, especially the Nāsadīya Sūkta, which begins: “The nonexistent did not exist, nor did the existent exist at that time” (Rig Veda 10.129.1, Jamison/Brereton translation). RV 10.72.2 says that for the oldest gods, “what exists was born from what does not exist”.

sn12.48:3.2.eng: “‘All does not exist’: this is the second cosmology.

sn12.48:4.2.eng: “‘All is oneness’: this is the third cosmology.
sn12.48:4.2.comm: After discussing existence for six lines, the seventh line of the Nāsadīya Sūkta begins, “That One breathed without wind by its independent will. There existed nothing else beyond that.” Then, “that One was born by the power of heat”. Thus the one is the immortal Divinity, confirming the commentary’s identification of this with eternalism (and the following with annihilationism). Similarly, RV 10.121 speaks of the anonymous Creator who “existed alone”.

sn12.48:5.1.comm: Puthutta is used elsewhere of a “spreading” poison, but only here in a philosophical sense. Throughout the Rig Veda, pṛthu is the broad expanse of earth or waters, spread out by Indra (eg. RV 10.113.4) and burned over by Agni (RV 10.156.3). It has sexual connotations, too: an ample womb (RV 10.99.2) or a fat ass (RV 10.86.8; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.2.5.16, 3.5.1.11). Thus while “oneness” suggests the Divinity that underlies all, “expansiveness” suggests the broad, pregnant world in which humans live. Thus the sacrificial cake should be spread expansively, but not too expansively, for that would make it human and therefore mortal (ŚB 1.2.2.9). In the Nāsadīya Sūkta instead of pṛthu we find tiraścīna (“stretched across”; the two terms are synonymous at ŚB 6.3.3.19) describing the searching minds of the sage-poets: “Their cord was stretched across: Did something exist below it? Did something exist above?” (RV 10.129.5). Moreover, Pali puthu stands for both Sanskrit pṛthu (“broad, wide, expansive”) and pṛthak (“separate, individual”). Both senses apply here, and indeed, they are not separate even in the Rig Veda, for things that proceed separately (pṛthak, rays of the sun, rivers, cows) spread out (pṛthu) across the broad earth (pṛthivī ).

sn12.48:5.2.eng: “‘All is expansiveness’: this is the fourth cosmology.

sn12.48:6.1.pli: Ete te, brāhmaṇa, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti:
sn12.48:6.1.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn12.48:6.3.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.48:6.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.48:6.5.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.48:6.7.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’”

sn12.48:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, lokāyatiko brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.48:7.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin cosmologist said to the Buddha,

sn12.48:7.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn12.49:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, a learned noble disciple doesn’t think:

sn12.49:1.4.pli: kismiṃ sati kiṃ hoti, kissuppādā kiṃ uppajjati?
sn12.49:1.4.eng: ‘When what exists, what is? Due to the arising of what, what arises?

sn12.49:1.5.pli: Kismiṃ sati saṅkhārā honti, kismiṃ sati viññāṇaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati nāmarūpaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati saḷāyatanaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati phasso hoti, kismiṃ sati vedanā hoti, kismiṃ sati taṇhā hoti, kismiṃ sati upādānaṃ hoti, kismiṃ sati bhavo hoti, kismiṃ sati jāti hoti, kismiṃ sati jarāmaraṇaṃ hotī’ti?
sn12.49:1.5.eng: When what exists do name and form come to be? When what exists do the six sense fields … contact … feeling … craving … grasping … continued existence … rebirth … old age and death come to be?’
sn12.49:1.5.comm: Choices and consciousness are included here in some editions, but the commentary clearly read them as absent, this being the only difference from the next discourse.

sn12.49:2.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sutavato ariyasāvakassa aparappaccayā ñāṇamevettha hoti:
sn12.49:2.1.eng: Rather, a learned noble disciple has only knowledge about this that is independent of others:

sn12.49:2.2.pli: ‘imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati.
sn12.49:2.2.eng: ‘When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.
sn12.49:2.2.comm: Each link is here expressed in the form of the first half of this formula, using the locative absolute construction (see note on SN 12.37:2.2).

sn12.49:2.3.eng: When ignorance exists choices come to be.

sn12.49:2.4.eng: When choices exist consciousness comes to be.

sn12.49:2.5.eng: When consciousness exists name and form come to be.

sn12.49:2.6.eng: When name and form exist the six sense fields come to be.

sn12.49:2.7.eng: When the six sense fields exist contact comes to be.

sn12.49:2.8.eng: When contact exists feeling comes to be.

sn12.49:2.9.eng: When feeling exists craving comes to be.

sn12.49:2.10.eng: When craving exists grasping comes to be.

sn12.49:2.11.eng: When grasping exists continued existence comes to be.

sn12.49:2.12.eng: When continued existence exists rebirth comes to be.

sn12.49:2.13.eng: When rebirth exists old age and death come to be.’

sn12.49:3.1.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sutavato ariyasāvakassa evaṃ hoti:
sn12.49:3.1.eng: A learned noble disciple doesn’t think:

sn12.49:3.3.pli: kismiṃ asati kiṃ na hoti, kissa nirodhā kiṃ nirujjhati?
sn12.49:3.3.eng: ‘When what doesn’t exist, what is not? Due to the cessation of what, what ceases?

sn12.49:3.4.pli: Kismiṃ asati saṅkhārā na honti, kismiṃ asati viññāṇaṃ na hoti, kismiṃ asati nāmarūpaṃ na hoti, kismiṃ asati saḷāyatanaṃ na hoti, kismiṃ asati phasso na hoti, kismiṃ asati vedanā na hoti, kismiṃ asati taṇhā na hoti, kismiṃ asati upādānaṃ na hoti, kismiṃ asati bhavo na hoti, kismiṃ asati jāti na hoti, kismiṃ asati jarāmaraṇaṃ na hotī’ti?
sn12.49:3.4.eng: When what doesn’t exist do choices not come to be? When what doesn’t exist do name and form not come to be? When what doesn’t exist do the six sense fields … contact … feeling … craving … grasping … continued existence … rebirth … old age and death not come to be?’

sn12.49:4.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sutavato ariyasāvakassa aparappaccayā ñāṇamevettha hoti:
sn12.49:4.1.eng: Rather, a learned noble disciple has only knowledge about this that is independent of others:

sn12.49:4.2.pli: ‘imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati.
sn12.49:4.2.eng: ‘When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases.

sn12.49:4.3.eng: When ignorance doesn’t exist choices don’t come to be.

sn12.49:4.4.eng: When choices don’t exist consciousness doesn’t come to be.

sn12.49:4.5.eng: When consciousness doesn’t exist name and form don’t come to be.

sn12.49:4.6.eng: When name and form don’t exist the six sense fields don’t come to be. …

sn12.49:4.7.eng: continued existence doesn’t come to be …

sn12.49:4.9.eng: When rebirth doesn’t exist old age and death don’t come to be.’

sn12.49:5.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ lokassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako diṭṭhisampanno itipi …pe…
sn12.49:5.1.eng: A noble disciple comes to truly understand the origin and disappearance of the world. Such a noble disciple is one who is called ‘one accomplished in view’, ‘one accomplished in vision’, ‘one who has come to the true teaching’, ‘one who sees this true teaching’, ‘one endowed with a trainee’s knowledge’, ‘one who has entered the stream of the teaching’, ‘a noble one with penetrative wisdom’, and also ‘one who stands knocking at the door to freedom from death’.”

sn12.5:1.1.eng: “Sikhī, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha …”
